problem_statement: Show step-by-step why any vector v âˆˆ R^3 can be written as a linear combination of the standard unit vectors i, j, k.
overview: Start from component (tuple) form, split the vector into coordinate contributions, factor out scalars, and then identify those basis directions with the standard unit vectors.

step_details.explanation: Define the standard unit vectors (basis of R^3).
expressions: $\mathbf i = \langle 1, 0, 0 \rangle, \quad \mathbf j = \langle 0, 1, 0 \rangle, \quad \mathbf k = \langle 0, 0, 1 \rangle \quad \color{blue}{\text{(unit length, pairwise perpendicular)}}$

step_details.explanation: Write an arbitrary vector in component form.
expressions: $\mathbf v = \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle \quad \color{blue}{\text{($v_1, v_2, v_3$ are its coordinates)}}$

step_details.explanation: Split v into the sum of three coordinate contributions (one per axis).
expressions: $\Rightarrow\; \langle v_1, v_2, v_3 \rangle = \langle v_1, 0, 0 \rangle + \langle 0, v_2, 0 \rangle + \langle 0, 0, v_3 \rangle \quad \color{blue}{\text{(add coordinates componentwise)}}$

step_details.explanation: Factor out the scalar in each contribution.
expressions: $\Rightarrow\; \langle v_1, 0, 0 \rangle = v_1\langle 1, 0, 0 \rangle,\; \langle 0, v_2, 0 \rangle = v_2\langle 0, 1, 0 \rangle,\; \langle 0, 0, v_3 \rangle = v_3\langle 0, 0, 1 \rangle$

step_details.explanation: Replace the tuples by the corresponding unit vectors.
expressions: $\Rightarrow\; \mathbf v = v_1\,\mathbf i + v_2\,\mathbf j + v_3\,\mathbf k \quad \color{blue}{\text{(linear combination of }\mathbf i,\mathbf j,\mathbf k\text{)}}$
$\htmlClass{light_green_box_large}{\mathbf v = v_1\,\mathbf i + v_2\,\mathbf j + v_3\,\mathbf k}\quad \color{blue}{\text{(final form)}}$

step_details.explanation: How to retrieve the coefficients (optional check).
expressions: $\Rightarrow\; v_1 = \mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf i,\; v_2 = \mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf j,\; v_3 = \mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf k \quad \color{blue}{\text{(because }\mathbf i,\mathbf j,\mathbf k\text{ are orthonormal)}}$
$\htmlClass{light_green_box_large}{\mathbf v = (\mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf i)\,\mathbf i + (\mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf j)\,\mathbf j + (\mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf k)\,\mathbf k}$
